content.user_title: Create Hookify Rules for Claude Code
content.value_statement: Stop repeating the same safety checks during coding. Add Hookify rules so Claude Code warns or blocks risky commands and edits.
actual_capabilities: Explain Hookify rule file structure using Markdown with YAML frontmatter
Guide users to configure events like bash, file, stop, prompt, and all
Provide pattern writing help for Python-style regex and common escaping pitfalls
Show how to use multi-condition rules with fields and operators
Offer examples for common safety and quality checks such as dangerous rm, console.log, and .env edits
limitations: Does not execute or validate rules inside your project automatically
Cannot guarantee the Hookify engine implementation details beyond the documented syntax
Regex guidance is general and may need adjustment for your specific commands and file contents
Does not replace security review or code review processes

use_cases.title: Prevent Risky Commands
use_cases.description: Add rules that warn or block rm -rf, chmod 777, and other dangerous bash operations during development.

use_cases.title: Reduce Debug Noise
use_cases.description: Detect console.log, debugger, and risky DOM patterns in file edits before they ship.

use_cases.title: Enforce Release Checks
use_cases.description: Use stop-event rules to require tests, builds, and documentation updates before ending a session.

prompt_templates.title: First Rule
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a Hookify rule that warns when I run rm -rf, using the minimal frontmatter fields.

prompt_templates.title: File Guard
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a Hookify file-event rule that warns when editing .env files and adding strings like API_KEY or SECRET.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-Condition
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a Hookify rule with conditions: only trigger when file_path ends with .ts or .tsx and new_text contains console.log(.

prompt_templates.title: Process Gate
prompt_templates.prompt: Write a stop-event Hookify rule that always triggers and shows a checklist for tests, build, and docs.

output_examples.input: Create a Hookify rule that warns on console.log in TypeScript files
output: Creates a rule name in kebab-case and sets enabled to true
Sets event to file and uses conditions for file_path and new_text
Uses a regex pattern that matches console.log( with proper escaping
Provides a short warning message with suggested alternatives

best_practices: Start with narrow patterns to reduce false positives
Use conditions to scope rules by file path and content fields
Test regex patterns on representative examples before relying on them
anti_patterns: Avoid overly broad regex like log that matches unrelated words
Avoid quoting patterns in YAML when it causes confusing escaping
Avoid relying on Hookify rules as your only security control

faq.question: Is this compatible with Claude Code?
faq.answer: Yes. It documents how to write Hookify rules intended for use with Claude Code workflows.

faq.question: What events can a rule trigger on?
faq.answer: The documented events are bash, file, stop, prompt, and all.

faq.question: Can a rule block an action or only warn?
faq.answer: It describes an optional action field with warn (default) and block, depending on event behavior.

faq.question: Does it read my files or send data anywhere?
faq.answer: No. This skill content is documentation only and contains no executable code or network behavior.

faq.question: Why does my regex not match as expected?
faq.answer: Common causes include missing escapes for special characters, patterns that are too broad or too specific, and YAML quoting that changes backslash handling.

faq.question: How is this different from manual reminders?
faq.answer: Rules let you standardize checks that trigger on specific events like commands, file edits, prompts, or stopping, instead of relying on memory.
